channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Many in Gaza City Ignore Israel’s Calls to Leave
item.description: Israel’s military dropped leaflets laying out four “safe corridors” for them to use to flee south, but few appeared to be heeding the warning on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘We Want Our Real Lives Back’: For Gazans, Egypt Is Safe, but It’s Not Home
item.description: Cairo now houses tens of thousands of Palestinians who fled the war in Gaza, with few job prospects, dwindling savings and no way to put their children in the local public schools.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Fatma Fahmy
item.media:credit: Fatma Fahmy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nahla al-Bashti, 60, who arrived in Egypt with her family from Gaza in December.

item.title: What NATO’s Warning to China Means
item.description: NATO’s rare rebuke of China could lead to actions pressuring the country to curb exports to Russia. Beijing denounced it as “prejudice, smears and provocation.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: World leaders including President Biden at the NATO summit in Washington, on Wednesday.

item.title: Kenya’s President Fires His Cabinet After Nationwide Protests
item.description: President William Ruto dismissed all but one of his cabinet secretaries after demonstrations over a finance bill that would have raised taxes led to the deaths of at least 41 people.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: President William Ruto of Kenya defended his record on Thursday, but said the electorate expected more from his government.

item.title: Russia Vows ‘Military Response’ to U.S. Missile Deployments in Germany
item.description: The U.S. and Germany announced episodic deployments of longer-range American missiles in Germany starting in 2026.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Paul Sonne
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: In a photo made available by the U.S. Navy, an American ship in the Middle East launched a Tomahawk cruise missile in 2014.

item.title: Canada Divided on How to Stop Drug Overdose Deaths
item.description: British Columbia’s partial retreat from an experiment to decriminalize drug possession reveals a political shift in Canada over combating the opioid crisis.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai and Alana Paterson
item.category: Vancouver Area Network of Drug Users
item.media:credit: Alana Paterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial wall for friends and family lost to illicit drug supply in the office at VANDU (The Vancouver Area Network of Drug Users). There have been recent tensions over the province’s harm-reduction approach.

item.title: France is Busing Homeless Immigrants Out of Paris Before the Olympics
item.description: The government promised housing elsewhere. We followed the buses and found a desperate situation.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of homeless people in front of City Hall in Paris. The police and courts have evicted roughly 5,000 people from around the city over the last year.

item.title: Three West African Countries Exit Regional ECOWAS Bloc
item.description: Burkina Faso, Mali and Niger are withdrawing from a 49-year-old regional alliance that has allowed goods and nearly 400 million people to travel freely across a tightly connected region.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Economic Community of West African States (Ecowas)
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: While absorbing the news of a fracture, heads of state and leaders of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) pose for a group photo at their meeting in Abuja on July 7.

item.title: Defeated by A.I., a Legend in the Board Game Go Warns: Get Ready for What’s Next
item.description: Lee Saedol was one of the world’s top Go players, and his shocking loss to an A.I. opponent was a harbinger of a new, unsettling era. “It may not be a happy ending,” he says.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: When an A.I. opponent defeated Lee Saedol, one of the world’s top Go players, it was seen as a harbinger of a new era for human-machine interactions.

item.title: Rwanda Says It Doesn’t Have to Repay UK for Scrapped Migration Plan
item.description: Britain gave Rwanda hundreds of millions of pounds, even though no asylum seekers were deported to the Central African nation under the agreement.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Britain had hoped the agreement would deter potential asylum seekers from trying to cross the English Channel in small boats.

item.title: A Biden Confidant Emerges as a Crucial Mideast Diplomat
item.description: Amos Hochstein, an energy policy official who was born in Israel, is playing diplomatic firefighter along the Israel-Lebanon border.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Amos Hochstein, special adviser to President Biden, in Beirut last month.

item.title: Macron Ends His Silence, Calling for ‘Broad Gathering’ That Would Split the Left
item.description: In an open letter, the French president rejected any role in government for the far-left France Unbowed party, setting the stage for a heated showdown.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France was in Washington on Wednesday for the NATO summit, but his open letter to the French people might set the stage for a confrontation with the ascendant left wing.

item.title: Kremlin Critic Vladimir Kara-Murza Is ‘Stable’ in Prison Hospital, Lawyer Says
item.description: Vladimir Kara-Murza’s legal representatives said they were denied access to their client in a remote Siberian penal colony for six days.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Vladimir Kara-Murza at a court hearing in Moscow in 2023. His lawyers said they were denied access to him for six days.

item.title: They Called It ‘Improper’ to Have Women in the Olympics. But She Persisted.
item.description: A century ago, Alice Milliat fought for the inclusion of female athletes in the Olympics. Her contribution, long overlooked, is now being recognized.
item.dc:creator: John Branch

item.title: Letter in The Lancet Raises Question of Excess Deaths in Gaza War
item.description: A letter in a major medical journal has prompted a discussion about the importance, and difficulty, of tallying those killed as an indirect result of the conflict between Israel and Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine
item.media:description: Bodies at a morgue in Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Will Allow Delivery of 500-pound Bombs to Israel, an Official Says
item.description: The bombs had been part of a shipment that President Biden withheld out of concerns over civilian deaths in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A crater in Jabaliya, a densely populated area just north of Gaza City, in October. The crater was created by a 2,000-pound bomb, according to experts and an analysis by The New York Times.

item.title: A ‘Simpsons’ Joke Comes True for Cypress Hill
item.description: The famed California hip-hop group played with the London Symphony Orchestra — 28 years after “The Simpsons” dreamed up the collaboration.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Sen Dog and B Real of Cypress Hill perform with the London Symphony Orchestra in London on Wednesday.

item.title: A Mammoth DNA Discovery Helps Map an Ancient Genome in 3-D
item.description: A “fossil chromosome” preserves the structure of a woolly mammoth’s genome — and offers a better grasp of how it once worked.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: Climate Activists in New York Protest Citibank and Other Backers of Big Oil
item.description: Amid soaring temperatures, hundreds of activists are staging boisterous blockades and solemn marches at banks and insurers that support fossil fuel projects.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Cara Buckley
item.media:description: A Summer of Heat on Wall Street protest near the headquarters of Citigroup in Manhattan on Wednesday.

item.title: Covering of Spire of Rouen Cathedral in France Catches Fire
item.description: The blaze appeared to cause minimal damage to the cathedral in Rouen, France, but measures were taken to protect its precious objects from any water damage.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Constant Méheut and Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the spire of the Rouen cathedral, in northern France, on Thursday.

item.title: Wife of ISIS Leader al-Baghdadi Is Sentenced to Death in Iraq
item.description: The woman was found guilty of helping the terrorist group detain and enslave women and girls of the Yazidi religious minority.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A ceremony held in January at a memorial monument in northern Iraq for Yazidis who were killed by Islamic State fighters.

item.title: Cooking Oil in Dirty Fuel Tankers? Report Raises Alarms in China.
item.description: Officials said they would start an investigation after a newspaper reported that a tanker used to carry liquefied coal was then used to transport soybean oil.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Cooking oil for sale in a Beijing supermarket this week.

item.title: NATO on the Edge: Biden Praises and Trump Denigrates a 75-Year Alliance
item.description: As leaders gathered in Washington to mark the anniversary of the organization, they heard starkly different messages from two American presidents on NATO’s future.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden meeting with world leaders at a NATO summit in Washington on Wednesday. “The fact that NATO remains the bulwark of global security did not happen by accident,” Mr. Biden said during the summit’s opening ceremony.

item.title: A.I. Helped to Spot a Copper Mining Bonanza in Zambia
item.description: The deposit, in Zambia, could make billions for Silicon Valley, provide minerals for the energy transition and help the United States in its rivalry with China.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak
item.media:credit: Zinyange Auntony for The New York Times
item.media:description: An exploration site run by KoBold Metals in Chililabombwe, Zambia, in June.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: A major declaration by NATO.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The heads of government of NATO member nations, at the summit in Washington.

item.title: Strike on Gaza School Compound Adds to Mounting Death Toll at U.N. Buildings
item.description: At least 27 people were killed when an Israeli airstrike exploded as people played soccer at a school turned shelter in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Damaged tents near a school turned shelter that was hit by an Israeli strike on the outskirts of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip.

item.title: Cease-Fire Negotiations Are Being Watched Closely by Hezbollah Leaders in Lebanon
item.description: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, warned that “the only way” to stop the cross-border hostilities between his group and Israel was to negotiate an end to the fighting in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the site of an Israeli airstrike in southern Lebanon on Thursday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Pressure Mounts for Biden to Step Aside
item.description: Plus, Israel urges Gaza City to evacuate.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nancy Pelosi, the congresswoman and former speaker of the House.

item.title: U.A.E. Tries 84 Emirates Again, Sentencing 43 to Life
item.description: The Emirati lawyers, academics and activists, who were imprisoned in national security trials, had been scheduled to be released.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: A protest in solidarity with political prisoners in Egypt and the United Arab Emirates on the sidelines of the U.N. climate talks in Dubai last year.

item.title: At NATO Summit, U.S. and Allies Aim for Ukraine Commitments That Will Endure
item.description: The specter of a second Donald J. Trump presidency injects new urgency into the NATO summit this week. President Biden and other leaders agree Ukraine should have an “irreversible” path to membership.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Julian E. Barnes and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky expressed thanks on Tuesday for the support given to Ukraine so far while prodding the Biden administration to continue relaxing its restrictions on the use of U.S. weapons in Russia.

item.title: 22 Years Ago, He Disappeared in an Avalanche. His Body Was Just Found.
item.description: Melting glaciers on Peru’s highest mountain helped uncover the body of Bill Stampfl, who disappeared while climbing the mountain with two friends.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Mitra Taj
item.media:description: Bill Stampfl was climbing Mount Huascarán with two friends in 2002 when an avalanche struck.

item.title: U.K. Police Find Man Suspected of Killing 3 Women With Crossbow
item.description: The women died at the scene near London on Tuesday, the police said. The BBC identified the victims as the wife and children of one of its commentators.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Jacob King/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Investigators at a house in Hertfordshire, England, where three women were killed on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Announces Tariffs on Chinese Metals Routed Through Mexico
item.description: The measure aims to close a loophole that officials said allowed metals made partly in China to come into the United States duty free.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: A steel facility in San Luis Potosi, Mexico. The Biden administration announced steps on Wednesday to impose tariffs on Chinese steel routed through Mexico.

item.title: Squirt Guns and ‘Go Home’ Signs: Barcelona Residents Take Aim at Tourists
item.description: Locals confronted visitors to the Catalan capital in a whimsical (but very serious) demonstration against mass tourism and housing shortages.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: A tourist watching as demonstrators protested against mass tourism in Barcelona on Saturday.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Biden at the NATO summit in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden is hosting the three-day NATO summit in Washington.

item.title: French Elections Show Battle for Europe’s Political Soul
item.description: A coarsening of public discourse and contempt for mainstream parties have politicians on both sides denouncing what they say are extreme positions by their opponents, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Celebrating France’s election results in Paris on Sunday. The leftist coalition won the most seats in the lower chamber of Parliament, but analysts fear political gridlock.

item.title: Euro 2024’s Best Party Invite: Meet at the Bus. And Wear Orange.
item.description: With thousands of voices and a few well-choreographed dance moves, Dutch fans have transformed match days into pulsing, joyous celebrations. Their next one is Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Rory Smith
item.media:description: The Dutch soccer federation expected more than 75,000 fans to turn up in Dortmund for Wednesday’s semifinal against England. They may have underestimated the crowd.

item.title: Berlin Honors Earliest Settlers, Whose Bones Shared Their Secrets
item.description: Archaeologists unearthed some 4,000 ancient skeletons from the heart of the city. After years of study, they were reinterred in a rare and solemn tribute.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral service for the early settlers of Berlin had miniature wooden coffins that contained the remains of children from ancient times.

item.title: Why Venezuelans Abroad Can’t Vote in Their Country’s Presidential Election
item.description: Many Venezuelans who left their homeland oppose the country’s autocratic president, but strict requirements will prevent most from voting in a closely watched election.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Venezuelan Consulate in Madrid. Some Venezuelans said they arrived hours before the consulate opened to try to register to vote in July’s election, but were unsuccessful.

item.title: As Violence Surges, Can Pakistan Protect Its Chinese Projects?
item.description: China has invested billions in megaprojects across Pakistan. But a resurgence in militant violence is threatening to derail badly needed investment.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Moving a victim’s body after a March suicide bombing that killed Chinese workers in Bisham, Pakistan.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: NATO Summit Begins
item.description: Plus, the U.S. says Russia is struggling in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Thirty-eight world leaders are in Washington for the NATO summit.

item.title: WADA Clears Itself in Chinese Doping Case
item.description: A special prosecutor said the decision not to pursue punishments against a group of Olympic swimmers was “indisputably reasonable,” even though agency scientists had expressed doubts.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Chinese swimmers won three golds at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021, and are favored to win more at the Paris Games.

item.title: Hezbollah Launches Retaliatory Rockets After Israel Appears to Strike in Syria
item.description: Two members of Hezbollah were reported killed in Syria, near the border with Lebanon, and the Israeli police said that the Hezbollah rocket barrage that followed killed a man and a woman in the Golan Heights.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Israeli police officers secured a road in the Golan Heights as rockets were launched from southern Lebanon, on Tuesday.

item.title: A Children’s Hospital in Ukraine Becomes a Scene of Destruction
item.description: Families and patients were not unfamiliar with the sound of missiles flying overhead. But the Russian assault on the hospital marked one of the worst days of violence against civilians in months.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

item.title: Russian Court Orders Arrest of Navalny’s Widow, Yulia Navalnaya
item.description: The court accused Ms. Navalnaya, who left Russia in 2021, of “participating in an extremist community.” She would be subject to arrest if she ever returns to Russia, the court said.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of Aleksei A. Navalny, the late Kremlin opposition leader, at a rally in March in Berlin, where voters lined up to cast their ballots in Russia’s presidential election.

item.title: Biden Is Hosting NATO This Week. Here’s What to Watch.
item.description: All eyes are on President Biden, but looming over the meeting is the possibility that Vladimir Putin might pull a stunt to disrupt the gathering.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley, Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden will meet with NATO leaders on Tuesday on the alliance’s 75th anniversary in Washington.

item.title: Indonesian Court Acquits Ex-Official Accused of Enslaving Addicts
item.description: The ex-regent had been accused of imprisoning hundreds of people under the guise of drug treatment and forcing them to work at his plantation and factory.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti for The New York Times
item.media:description: A plainclothes police officer inspecting a cage on the property of the former official, Terbit Rencana Perangin-angin, in North Sumatra, Indonesia, in 2022.

item.title: Cigarette Smuggling in Gaza Turns Aid Trucks Into Targets
item.description: Organized looters are attacking aid convoys in search of contraband cigarettes, officials say, as needed aid languishes.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman and Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: Cigarettes on sale in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, in March.

item.title: Modi’s Russia Visit Showcases a Less Isolated Putin, Angering Ukraine
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India made his first visit to Russia in five years, even as Ukraine reeled from an attack on a children’s hospital.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia greeting Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at a state residence outside Moscow on Monday, in an image released by Russian state media.

item.title: At Euro 2024, France Stars Pivot From Political Fight to a Soccer One
item.description: Some of the country’s top players had urged voters to reject the far right in a pivotal election. With that battle over, a date with Spain in Euro 2024 offers a more familiar challenge.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Didier Deschamps, the France coach, top left, and his players will face Spain on Tuesday in a Euro 2024 semifinal.

item.title: Archaeologists Find Marble Statue in Ancient Sewer in Bulgaria
item.description: Researchers in Bulgaria think the artifact could offer a window into ancient tensions around the rise of Christianity.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Archaeologists in southwest Bulgaria found a well-preserved statue by accident.

item.title: Is France’s Far-Left Firebrand, Jean-Luc Mélenchon, Ready to Govern?
item.description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon led his coalition to a narrow victory in elections. But even some of his allies bristle at the thought of the combative former Trotskyist becoming prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, right, after the second round of French legislative elections on Sunday. His tone and hard-line stance have given him a devoted, youthful following.

item.title: U.S. Officials Say Russia Is Unlikely to Take Much More Ukrainian Territory
item.description: Russian forces continue to inflict pain, but NATO leaders gathering in Washington can say that their efforts to strengthen Ukraine are working.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: Installing a trench line in eastern Ukraine last month. Russia’s incremental advances have been slowed by the Ukrainians’ hardened lines in recent months.

item.title: Why Kenyan Police Officers Are Deployed in Haiti
item.description: About 400 Kenyan officers have deployed to Haiti as part of the first wave of a multinational contingent tasked with trying to restore order in the gang-plagued Caribbean nation.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Haitian and Kenyan police officers in Port-au-Prince, Haiti’s capital, late last month.

item.title: IDF Leader Denounces Jewish Settler Violence in West Bank
item.description: Maj. Gen. Yehuda Fuks, the outgoing chief of Israel’s Central Command, rebuked the Israeli government’s policies in the West Bank and condemned “nationalist crime” by Jewish settlers.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evyatar, in the northern West Bank, is one of five settler outposts that Israel recently decided to give legal status. Settlements in the territory are widely considered to be illegal under international law.

item.title: How Swizz Beatz Climbed to the Top of Saudi Arabia’s Camel Racing Scene
item.description: “I’m just bringing the cool factor to it,” said the American hip-hop producer, who has spent millions of dollars on 48 camels for a team he calls “Saudi Bronx.”
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:credit: Iman Al-Dabbagh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Swizz Beatz, an American hip-hop producer whose real name is Kasseem Dean, at the AlUla Camel Cup after his camel Enzo won fourth place this spring.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The fallout from France’s election.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Near Place de la République in Paris, after results were announced Sunday.

item.title: Starmer Is Aligned With Biden, but How Would That Change With Trump?
item.description: Politically aligned, Joe Biden and the new U.K. prime minister agree on climate change, Ukraine and Northern Ireland. Donald Trump would be a different story.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Britain’s incoming prime minister and leader of the Labour Party, Keir Starmer, and his wife, Victoria, are greeted as they arrive inside 10 Downing Street.

item.title: As NATO Summit Convenes, Leaders Worry About Biden’s Uncertain Future
item.description: A summit meant to convey confidence in the newly expanded alliance opened with a dazzling celebration and no mention of President Biden’s political peril.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Biden with other world leaders on Tuesday at the 75th celebration of NATO’s creation in Washington.
